intro: Lappula stricta, commonly known as narrowleaf lappula, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It typically grows to a height of 20–60 cm and has erect, branching stems that are often hairy. The leaves are alternate, lanceolate, and usually have a rough texture with prominent veins. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers in clusters, which are followed by bead-like, ribbed seeds. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in fields, roadsides, and waste areas.
